repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.abstract: This collection contains the administrative records of Gelman Library. The materials include photographs, negatives, office records, building plans, posters, correspondence, and publications. They range in date from ca 1825-2005.

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Gelman Library Administration records, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Series 41 and 51 are closed to research for 25 years from date of record creation.. Series 53 and 54 are closed to research for 50 years from date of record creation.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

bioghist.head: Historical or Biographical Note
bioghist.p: President Cloyd Heck Marvin, inaugurated in 1927, undertook a plan to bring the university curriculum and facilities up to 20th-century standards. A major part of the plan was the construction of a library building, the first in the University's history. In the fall semester of 1939, the Lisner Library, located on G Street between 20th and 21st streets, opened. The facility had a total of six floors and was entirely dedicated to library offices and stacks, which housed a collection of 119,000 volumes.

By 1954, the Library contained 270,000 volumes. One major increase came through the 1950 purchase of the library of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, adding more than 50,000 volumes to the stacks of both the Lisner Library and the Burns Library at the National Law Center.

In 1950, Matilda Wright donated to the Library her brother's collection of material on Washington, D.C., history. As the finest privately held collection of books, pamphlets, manuscripts, photographs, and artwork on the topic, these 1,500 items formed the core around which the Special Collections Department was built.

Despite this progress, the University Library compared unfavorably to other universities in terms of funding, staff, and collections. This was due to the faulty belief that the rich library resources of Washington were accessible to GW students and faculty as a substitute for onsite collections.

It was not until the beginning of Lloyd H. Elliott's presidency, in 1965, however, that significant improvement began to be made. Elliott declared that the development of a true research library for the University was his first priority. In 1966, he implemented a plan to increase the book budget. He also set up a building committee to develop a new research library building that could hold 1,000,000 volumes and seat 2,500 readers. The new Gelman Library opened in the fall of 1973 with a collection of 429,778 volumes. The following year, the collection passed the 500,000 volume mark. Mrs. Estelle Gelman, endowed the Library with $1,500,000 for unrestricted library development in 1980. The Library recognized the importance of her contribution by naming the University Library in honor of her late husband, Melvin Gelman. In 1984, Gelman Library marked the addition of its one-millionth volume to the collection and the library has been expanding rapidly ever since. A major acquisition was a gift from Ari and Phyllis Kiev of the I. Edward Kiev Collection on Judaica, which contains more than 20,000 volumes on religion, philosophy, classics and art.

In 2001, the Gelman Library raised funds for the two-millionth volume, An Illustrated Atlas; Geographical Statistical and Historical, of the Unites States, and the Adjacent Countries by T. G. Bradford; Boston, Weeks, Jordan [1838], and the two-million-and-first volume, Web of Science. The official Two-millionth Volume of The Gelman Library System is a rare book acquired through a gift from James Cecil King, a grateful alumnus, professor emeritus, bibliophile, writer and an ardent patron of The Melvin Gelman Library.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the administrative records of Gelman Library. The materials include photographs, negatives, office records, building plans, posters, correspondence, and publications. They range in date from ca 1825-2005.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into 56 series (there is no series 2). They include eighteen series of office records, eleven series with photographs, three series with negatives, two series with correspondence, two series of newsletters, and two series of posters. Single series include manuals; construction specifications; grant files; remodeling documents; by-laws; systems project; event materials; proposals; building plans; publication layouts; records and memos; blueprints; videotape; accession logs; t-shirts; and Andrea Stewart records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains annual reports, correspondence, budgets, agendas, reports, guidelines, forms, committee reports, plans, surveys, registration card, brochures, mission statement, strategic plans, bookmarks, newsletters, bookplates, statistics, list library staff, organization charts, strategic planning, instructions, comment cards, buttons, studies, memorandums, procedures, conference proceedings, handbooks, programs, news articles, press releases, stickers, guides, proposals, and floor plans. They range in date from circa 1825 to 2004. The items concern the Administrative Council, work schedules, Gelman Library, library policies, job performance, job descriptions, Anglo-American Cataloging Rues 2 (AACR2), OCLC, RLG, RLIN, automation systems, incident reports, Jacob Burns Law Library annual reports, Himmelfarb Health Sciences Library (Medical Library) annual reports, Hospital Library annual reports, Acquisitions, serials, Circulation Department, reserve desk, International Relations collection, Catalog Department, donors, Reference Department, the institute for Sino-Soviet Studies Library, exhibits, library partnerships, cataloging, Study of bar code and light pen circulation systems, continuing eductions, preservation, conservation, audiovisual materials, Council of the Librarians, librarian ethics, disaster recovery plan, library exhibits, faculty orientation, Linser Library, inventories, the Library Council, Columbian College, Media Resources Department, the move to H Street, staff party events, one millionth book, two millionth book, Gelman Library's tenth anniversary, library staff, system operations, telecommunications, Television News Study Center, and University Librarians.
Formerly vertical files

did.abstract: This accession log records book accessions made by The George Washington University library between August 1, 1947 - August 17, 1948. Different than the older Dewey Accession Logs, this log is typewritten and includes details on 18,800 items acquired during that time. Details noted include the accessions' title, author, date acquired, volume number, cost, publication year, and source including various donors. Handwritten notations of withdrawal or discarding included on some items in the margins. Folder 1/4 of Volume O, rehoused from original binder into folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These office files belonged to University Librarian Jack Siggins. Files include Faculty Senate records, library budgets, financial reports, and newsletters. They range in date from 1988-2005. They were transfered to the University Archives in 2006.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: These records are not yet processed and no series have been determined. The box inventory appears to be a list of the titles of binders. The binders remain in original order with orginal titles.

scopecontent.head: Box level inventory
scopecontent.p: All this data comes from description pages attached to the outside of the box. We can presume these descriptions were prepared by Andrea Stewart.
Box 1: Learning Organization; Banner/Alumni Development Gift Journal 2004-2005; Admin 2004; Orientation/Library Information; GW 2004; LAMA Leadership Development Committee

Box 2: Development Group 2004; Development-Annual Fund 2003-2004 & 2004-2005; Alternative Academic Calendar 1 of 3; Alternative Academic Schedule 200 2 of 3; Alternative Academic Calendar 3 of 3; LibQUAL+ Spring 2003
Box 3: Admin 2002; Admin Binder 2003; CHRON 2003; Academic Excellence 2003; Budget June 2002
Box 4: Development Reports 2005; ASPP Fall 2001-Spring 2005; Admin 2005; Development Letters 2005; Friends of GW Libraries 2005; Oracle Training; Customer Service Workshop
Box 5: User Survey 1997; ALA Binder 2003-2004; Annual Report 2003; ASPP Fall 1998-Spring 2001; The Gelman Library System Annual Report 2003-2004; ASSESS 2003; 1987 User Survey
Box 6: 1994 User Survey Book 1; 1994 User Survey Book II; 1994 User Survey Book III; 1994 User Survey Book IV

Box 7: Human Resources Binder FY 2000; Council of Librarians Files from June 30, 1992 and Before; Strategic Planning Group FY 1999; Statstics Oline Project 2002; Friends 2004; Strategic Planning Group FY 2000-FY 2002; Human Resources Binder FY 2001

Box 8: banner/Alumni Development Gift Journal FY 2001-2003; Library Journal; CHRON 2004; LTF4; Development Group February 1, 2001 to June 2, 2003; The Gelman Library System Annual Report 2202-2003; The Gelman Library System Annual Report 2001-2002; Annual Report 2002-2001
Box 9: Develpment Group June 2, 2003 to December 2003; User Survey 1990; Donor Database Users Group 2002; Goal II Stat. Plan 2002-2005; SMG 2003-2004
Box 10: JAS-Credenza Notes Nov. 2002-June 2006; ALA CPE Focus on Library Support June 2003; SPACE Ja. 1999-[2005]; ASSESS 2001

Box 11 (added later): Contains 1 folder with the following contents: 1) Program for the acceptance of the Gilbert Stuart Portrait (1/28/1983) 2) Gelman Tenth Anniversary Dinner at Cosmos Club (3/30/1984) 3) Reception for Sharon Rogers, University Librarian (7/12/1984) 4) Tenth Anniversary of Gelman Library Building (3/9/1984)

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: These files were accessioned upon the clean-out of filing cabinets previously belonging to Andrea Stewart and Jack Siggins, which had been moved to a storage room. Part of accession 2016-002.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: During the time period covered by these files, Andrea Stewart served as the Assistant University Librarian for Administration and Human Resources (2000-2003) and the Associate University Librarian for Administration, Human Resources and Development (2003-2012) under University Librarian Jack Siggins.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In 2002, the mayor of DC proclaimed May 2, 2002 as Melvin Gelman Library Day. The Gelman Library had been working to strengthen its African American resources, and the day was chosen in memory of the 34th anniversary of the assissination of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
